title-group.article-title: Analysis of a complete model of rotating machinery excited by magnetic actuator system

abstract.p: Rotating machines have a wide range of application involving shafts rotating at high speeds that must have high confidence levels of operation. Therefore, the dynamic behavior analysis of such rotating systems is required to establish operational patterns of the equipment, providing the basis for controller development in order to reduce vibrations or even to control oil instabilities in lubricated bearings. A classical technique applied in parameter identification of machines and structures is the modal analysis, which consists of applying a perturbation force into the system and then to measure its response. However, there are mainly two problems in modal analysis concerning the excitation of rotating systems. First, there are limitations to the excitation of systems with rotating shafts when using impact hammers or shakers, due to friction, undesired tangential forces, and noise that can be introduced in the system response. The second problem relies in the difficulty of exciting backward whirl modes, an inherent characteristic from these systems. Therefore, the study of a non-contact technique of external excitation, also capable of exciting backward whirl modes, becomes of high interest. In this sense, this article deals with the study and modeling of a magnetic actuator, used as an external excitation source for a rotating machine, mainly in backward whirl mode. Special attention is given to the actuator model and its interaction with the rotor system. Differently from previous works with similar proposal, which uses current and air gap measurements, here the external excitation force control is based on the magnetic field directly measured by hall sensor positioned in the pole center of the magnetic actuator core. The magnetic actuator design was completely developed for this purpose, opening different paths to experimental application of this device, for example, fault detection analysis based on directional modes. It is also presented a comparison between the numerical simulations and practical tests obtained from a rotor test rig and an experimental evidence of the backward whirl was accomplished based on the numerical simulation results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An important phenomenon, observed in every rotating machine, is the presence of forward and backward precession modes which are strongly related to the non-symmetry and the anisotropy of the system. In many cases, the anisotropy comes from the bearings, in particular, journal bearings. Many authors1–3 developed models of complementary components to fully represent rotating systems, such as bearings, couplings, and seals, and integrated them with the shaft finite element models (FEMs),4,5 opening the study of the phenomena inherent to the complete systems. In order to include the bearing effects, Lund6 was the first researcher to propose the calculus of equivalent dynamic. An analysis and comparison between several methods for calculating the dynamic coefficients of journal bearings were carried out by Silva.7 Machado and Cavalca8 used a finite volume method to solve the Reynolds equation for cylindrical, elliptical, and three-lobe bearings and calculated the dynamic coefficients from the pressure distribution. Castro et al.9 studied a non-linear model for the hydrodynamic forces10 and evaluated non-linear dynamic coefficients to represent the bearings sustaining forces.

Lee11 developed the complex modal analysis, which made easier to distinguish between forward and backward modes. Dias and Allemang12 studied the existence of mixed operational modes, i.e. modes where part of the rotor is in forward whirl and part in backward whirl, using the shape and directivity index plot, which shows the direction of each station of the machine through the analyzed frequency range. Mesquita et al.13 compared the traditional frequency response function (FRF) with the directional FRF (dFRF) in the rotor dynamic analysis. The identification of natural and operational modes using complex coordinates was the focus of the work of Kessler.14 Santana et al.15 used the dFRF to study the anisotropy degree influence (of the foundation and the journal bearings) over the backward precessional modes.

Concerning to non-contact excitation source, the works of Chiba et al.16 and Maslen17 are well-known references in this field. They deal with the development of magnetic actuators including the differential linearization, where two actuators are radially and oppositely placed. Once magnetic actuators can generate only attractive forces, this positioning allows applying forces in both ways of the actuator direction and also linearizes the magnetic force. Magnetic actuators are mainly composed of solenoids, which basically consist of coils wound on a core of ferromagnetic material. When a current is applied to the coils, a magnetic field is induced in its ferromagnetic core, generating the magnetic force.

The numerous publications about magnetic bearings not only focused in the control aspects of bearing applications, but also in its use in modal analysis and structural health monitoring or failure detection, reflect the growing importance of this component in the role of rotating machinery, and the education process of research groups within this area of knowledge; see, for instance, the works done by many authors.18–23

Furtado24 developed a one direction magnetic actuator and applied it as an excitation source in a classical modal analysis procedure. In his work, constructive aspects concerning magnetic actuators can be found as in Castro et al.25 and Furtado et al.26–28 A biaxial magnetic actuator was developed by Mendes29 and its constructive aspects can also be found in Mendes et al.30 A simulated classical modal analysis, using a FEM of the same rotor in the work of Furtado24 but with the model of the biaxial actuator, is presented in Mendes et al.31

The use of the biaxial actuator, based on magnetic field measurements to control the external force applied for complex modal analysis, is the topic of current research. Differently from previous works with similar proposal, which uses current and air gap measurements; here, the external excitation force control is based on the magnetic field directly measured by hall sensor positioned in the pole center of the magnetic actuator core.

The rotating system was represented by the FEM of the shaft and the linear dynamic coefficients of the journal bearings. Special attention was given to the actuator model that was completely developed for this purpose, opening different paths to experimental application of this device. Simulations of the complete system (actuator and rotor) were compared with experimental results in order to show the expressiveness of the model and the actuator ability to excite forward and backward modes. A series of numerical simulations was processed to study the precession direction transition between forward and backward. An experimental evidence of the backward whirl, rarely found in the literature, was accomplished based on the numerical simulation results. This article presents the theoretical and experimental developments in a didactic progressive way and, consequently, it can be widely used by researchers at different degrees of education and knowledge about this topic.

sec.title: Mechanical system
sec.p:
Figure 1(a) shows the mechanical system which contains a steel SAE 1030 shaft of 12 mm diameter and 800 mm length, with 94.82 mm diameter and 47.5 mm width disc placed at the mid-span of the shaft, and a journal of 80 mm length and 40 mm diameter placed at 62 mm of the first bearing, both made of steel SAE 1020. The system is supported by two hydrodynamic bearings symmetrically placed 600 mm from each other, both with 90 µm clearance, 20 mm width, and 30 mm inner diameter. The lubricant used in this mechanical system is the ISO VG 32 oil. Figure 1.
(a) Test rig and (b) FEM of the mechanical system. FEM: finite element model.

The FEM of this system is shown in Figure 1(b). The shaft was split into 20 elements (upper numbers) and 21 nodes (lower numbers), and the position of the bearings are pointed by triangles. The matrices used in the model were obtained from Nelson and McVaugh4 (1)Mq··(t)+(C+ΩG)q·(t)+Kq(t)=F(t) (2)M=MT+MR

The equation of motion is given in equation (1), where Ω is the rotational speed, M the mass matrix, G the gyroscopic matrix, K the stiffness matrix, and C the damping matrix (proportional to K according to Weiming and Novak32) and, in this case, adjusted by a factor of 2 × 10−4.15 Besides, the matrix M is obtained from the sum of two matrices (equation (2)): the rotational mass matrix MR and the translational mass matrix MT. The term F(t) is the external forces vector, in this case, due to an unbalanced mass and the actuator force and q the generalized coordinate vector, with two translational and two rotational degrees of freedom (DOFs) for each node.

The journal bearings are modeled by equivalent coefficients of stiffness and damping (Figure 2), added to the corresponding DOF at the bearings location in the stiffness and damping matrixes of the system, respectively. The dynamic coefficients are evaluated from Machado and Cavalca8 and Machado33 by the solution of the Reynolds equation (equation (3)) using finite volume method. (3)∂∂y(h3∂p∂y)+∂∂x(h3∂p∂x)=6ηΩ∂h∂y+12η∂h∂t Figure 2.
Model of the journal bearing.

In equation (3), x is the axial coordinate, y the circumferential coordinate, η the viscosity of the fluid, h the fluid film thickness, p the pressure, and t the time. The dynamic coefficients behavior dependence on the rotational speed is shown in Figure 3(a) and (b). Figure 3.
(a) Stiffness coefficients and (b) damping coefficients.

The solution of the homogeneous part of equation (1) provides the natural frequencies and natural modes of the system. However, it can be seen that equation (1) depends on the rotational speed, i.e. the properties of the system changes as the rotational speed changes. Therefore, this effect is shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), which show the Campbell diagram and the variation of the modal damping, respectively. The points where the natural frequencies cross the 1X line are called critical velocities. In rotor dynamics, the precession movements (also called whirl) can be forward, if they occur in the same direction of the rotor spin, or backward, if in the opposite direction.11 Thus, natural frequencies and the natural modes receive the denomination of forward or backward, depending on the direction of their associated precession mode. There is an important issue concerning to backward modes, once the shaft develops this kind of precession, its inner stress state keeps changing from tension to compression, which may cause the premature failure by fatigue. In this sense, it is important to identify these modes to prevent the rotor to operate in this condition. Figure 4.
(a) Campbell diagram; (b) modal damping of the natural modes; (c) first forward bending mode; (d) first backward bending mode; and (e) ODS. ODS: operational deflection shape.

Despite common intuition, the unbalance, which is a synchronous force, can excite backward whirling modes strongly due to the stiffness asymmetry of the bearings. Greenhill and Cornejo34 showed in their work that critical speeds can also result from backward modes resonance. Therefore, it is important to study backward modes since the anisotropy is a primary characteristic of journal bearings. The natural modes, for a rotational speed of 35 Hz, are presented in Figure 4(c) and (d). Figure 4(c) presents the first forward bending mode of the shaft and Figure 4(d) the first backward one. The particular solution of equation (1), regarding to the unbalance, gives the operational deflection shape (ODS), as shown in Figure 4(e), for the rotational speed 35 Hz. The ODS presents the relative motion between two or more degrees of freedom from a structure due to an external excitation force,35 and it gives an pretty good idea of how the system responds in a specific frequency, considering the response of the system as a linear combination of its natural modes.

Still concerning to journal bearings, in the modal damping variation graphic (Figure 4(b)), it can be seen that, around 46 Hz, the damping of the first forward bending mode becomes negative, i.e. the dynamic behavior of the fluid film bearings is unstable. This is an effect of the fluid-induced instability (oil-whip) that occurs when the rotational speed reaches nearly twice the frequency of the first forward bending mode.9,36,37

sec.title: Magnetic system
sec.p: In the work of many authors16,17,21,38 who used magnetic bearings, the control system is based on the shaft displacement and the current passing through the coils, once the bearings have to levitate the shaft, no matter the necessary force.

However, the magnetic actuator, applied as an external exciter, has a different concept; the objective is to guarantee that the desired force is applied to the rotating system, regardless to the coils current or the shaft position. As previously known, the magnetic force is proportional to the magnetic field, which means that if the necessary magnetic field (Bref) is insured, the magnetic force is insured. Hence, the control of the magnetic actuator is based on the magnetic flux control.24

The magnetic actuator system (Figure 5) is composed by the actuator itself, a pulse-width modulation (PWM) power amplifier in order to transform the voltage from the controller into the correspondent current to the coils, and the hall sensor, which closes the feedback control loop. The model of each part of the system is described in the following four sections, while in the fifth section, an overview of the entire model and how its equations are related is presented. Figure 5.
Magnetic actuator system.

sec.title: Magnetic field and magnetic force
sec.p: The calculus of the magnetic field can be performed through a law developed by André Marie Ampère (1775–1836), shown in equation (4) (4)∮H·dl=∑i

The Ampere law states that the integral of the magnetic field intensity (H) over a closed line (denoted Amperian curve), dl, is equal to the liquid current (i) that passes through the surface limited by the integration path39 (5)H=Bμ

The magnetic flux density (or magnetic field) can be obtained by a relation between the magnetic field intensity (B) and an intrinsic property of the material, called magnetic permeability (μ), as shown in equation (5).

Therefore, for the magnetic system shown in Figure 6, equation (6) can be obtained from equations (4) and (5) (6)N·i=B·(2·lgμg+lsμs+lcμc) where N is the number of coils and l the Amperian curve length. The subscripts g, s, and c refer to air gap, shaft, and core, respectively. Figure 6.
Magnetic circuit and Amperian curve.
Considering that the shaft and the core magnetic permeabilities are much higher than the air magnetic permeability, these terms can be neglected,16 leading to equation (7) (7)B=μg·N·i2·lg

According to Sen,40 the energy stored in the magnetic field (Wf) can be obtained by equation (8) (8)Wf=B22·μg·vg (9)vg=2·Ag·lg where the volume of the air gap (vg), equation (9), is as a function of the pole area (Ag) and air gap length (lg).

Finally, the magnetic force in equation (10) is obtained differentiating the magnetic field energy in respect to the space; the minus signal symbolize that magnetic actuators can only generate attractive forces (10)Fm=-dWfdx=-B2·Agμg
Remark 1
The factor 2 in the volume equation (equation (9)) and also in equation (6) is due to the fact that there is one air gap for each pole of the actuator.

Analyzing equation (10), it is clear that insuring the magnetic field is a sufficient condition to insure the magnetic force, once the other terms of the equation are constant. On the other hand, the magnetic field (equation (7)) depends on the variation of the current and the air gap. The air gap, which changes with the shaft vibration (precession movement or whirl), is the parameter to be compensated by the control loop; and this compensation is made through the current sent to the actuator coils.

sec.title: Magnetic force linearization
sec.p:
As magnetic actuators provide only attractive forces, a differential assembly (Figure 7) is used17 and the resultant force is presented in equation (11) (11)Fm=Agμg(B12-B22) Figure 7.
Differential assembly.
In order to linearize the force, a bias magnetic field is used (equation (12)) (12)B1=Bb+B*B2=Bb-B* where B* is the variable field and Bb the bias field.24

Therefore, equation (13) presents the linearized magnetic force, and it can be manipulated to calculate the necessary variable magnetic field (B*) for a given magnetic force as shown in equation (14) (13)Fm=Agμg4BbB* (14)B*=Fmμg4BbAg

Another function of the bias field is to prevent the magnetic flux to change its direction, avoiding losses in the magnetic circuit. Thus, to calculate the minimum magnetic bias field necessary, the maximum force (Fmax) that must be applied by the actuator should be taken into account. Therefore, the maximum force (without changing the direction of the magnetic field) is obtained when the variable and the bias fluxes are equal (equation (15)) (15)Bb=Bmax*
Replacing this condition in equation (13), the bias magnetic flux can be obtained as shown in equation (16) (16)Bb=Fmax·μg4·Ag

sec.title: Hall sensor and controller
sec.p: Once the reference magnetic field is calculated, as shown in equation (12), it is compared in the control loop with the measured field. This measurement is performed by a hall sensor, which is modeled as a first-order differential equation, as shown in equation (17) (17)VhBh=KhThs+1

In equation (17), a gain (Kh) and a time constant (Th) are both provided by the manufacturer. Remark 2
It is important to notice that, before the comparison, the reference magnetic field should be also multiplied by the hall sensor gain, in order to be converted to a correspondent voltage.

The error, difference between the reference field and the measured field, is the input of the controller. Marszolek41 compared three kinds of controller (P (proportional), PD (proportional–derivative), and PID (proportional–integral–derivative)) and all of them obtained a similar performance. Later, Furtado24 used a P controller and obtained acceptable results for this application. Therefore, in this study, a proportional controller (Kp) is used.

sec.title: PWM amplifier
sec.p:
In order to amplify the signal sent from the controllers to the coils, a PWM amplifier is used. Furthermore, the amplifier convert the input voltage in the amplified correspondent current, because, as equation (7) shows, the magnetic field is not proportional to the voltage, but to the current. The amplifier behavior is linear in the range of interest; hence, it is described by a polynomial equation of first order, as shown in equation (18) (18)Iout=c1·Vin+c2 where Iout is the output current and Vin the input voltage. The coefficients c1 and c2 are estimated based on a measured calibration curve, presented in Figure 8. Remark 3
The electric system is a first-order system (known as RL circuit) composed by the inductance (LB) of the actuator coil and its resistance (RB), as shown in Figure 9. Figure 8.
Amplifier calibration curve.
Figure 9.
Electric system of the magnetic actuator.

The fact that the electric system has its behavior governed by a first-order differential equation implies that it has an associated dynamic. In order to avoid dealing with this dynamic, the PWM amplifier was used in the current control mode, which has an internal controller to insure that the output current (Iout) is proportional to the input voltage (Vin) regardless to the dynamic of the system.

Therefore, it should be pointed out the difference between the role of the PWM internal controller and the controller of the magnetic actuator system. The first one is responsible to insure that the current sent to the coils is linearly proportional to the output voltage of the second one, which has the function of compensate the variation of the air gap, i.e. compensate the magnetic field variation, insuring the desired force.

sec.title: Complete actuator system
sec.p:
Once the model of the entire system was presented, the schematic of the whole set of equations and their interconnections is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Schematic of the interconnections between the equations of the magnetic system.

As stated before, the control of the magnetic actuator is based on the magnetic field. Therefore, in order to obtain the desired external excitation force (Fm), it must be written in terms of magnetic field. According to ‘Magnetic force linearization’ section, this is done through the bias magnetic field (Bb) and the variable magnetic field (B*).

Initially, the bias magnetic field (Bb) must be evaluated from equation (16) considering the maximum amplitude of the force to be applied by the actuator (Fmax). In the next step, the variable magnetic field (B*) is evaluated through equation (14).

Thus, according to the linearization, one actuator receives the sum of the correspondent field (B*) and the bias magnetic field (Bb), and the diametrically opposed actuator receives its subtraction (Figure 7 and equation (12)).

Next, the resultant magnetic field is multiplied by the hall sensor gain (Kh), so it is transformed in a voltage that can be compared with the hall sensor measurement (Vh). The difference between these voltages is the input of the proportional controller (Kp), which sends the voltage control signal (Vin) to the PWM amplifier (equation (18)). The amplifier sends the current (i) to the actuator coils.

The dotted line represents the magnetic actuator itself and, as observed in Figure 10, it is represented by equations (7) and (10). The current provided by the PWM amplifier is the input of equation (7) which calculates the generated magnetic field (B). Through the generated field (B), equation (10) calculates the obtained magnetic force (F). Also, this magnetic field B (‘to be measured’) is the input of the hall sensor equation (17) and its correspondent voltage (Vh) closes the control loop.

Therefore, the magnetic system is ready to be incorporated to the mechanical system. Remark 4
The air gap (lg) in the first actuator equation (7) is not the nominal actuator air gap, but the nominal air gap minus the shaft displacement (obtained from the mechanical system).

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p:
The experimental setup is presented in Figure 11. The mass displacement measurements are taken by two proximity sensors and the journal bearing displacements by four proximity sensors that worked immersed in the oil film of the bearings. The six sensors were used with their respective signal conditioners and all their signals pass through two filters before being acquired: a DC offset filter and an anti-aliasing filter. The interface between the computer and the system is made by a general purpose control card AT-MIO-16-E2 from ‘National Instruments’. Figure 11.
Experimental setup.
The test rig also has a three-phase motor and a frequency inverter CFW-08, both from ‘WEG’, and the communication with the PC is made through a serial communication module XC8, also from ‘WEG’.

sec.title: Simulated and experimental results
sec.p: As stated before, in rotor dynamics, the precession movements can be forward, if they occur in the same direction of the rotor spin, or backward, if in the opposite direction. In order to separate these two components of motion in the spectrum of the time domain, the concept of the Fourier transform of real signals can be expanded for complex signals, using the complex exponential, as presented in Goldman and Muszynska.42 This spectrum is referred in the literature by the term full spectrum.42–46 Hence, the positive part of the full spectrum represents the forward precession and, analogously, the negative part, the backward precession. The direction (signal) of the peak with higher amplitude determines if the motion is predominantly forward or backward.

To validate the model, the frequency spectrum of the disc displacement from the numerical simulation and the experimental test are compared. The comparison is accomplished for two different rotational speeds (30 and 35 Hz) and three external excitation frequencies of the magnetic actuator (20, 25, and 30 Hz). In all cases, a sinusoidal force with magnitude of 10 N is used in one direction of the actuator x1 or x2 (Figure 12(a) and (b)). The air gap between the journal and the poles of the actuator is 1.7 mm. The duration of each measurement is 2 s. Figure 12.
(a) Magnetic actuator and (b) scheme of the actuator assembly.

The black dashed lines in Figure 13 refer to the experimental results and the gray lines to the simulated results. Figure 13.
Numerical simulations (gray lines) and practical tests obtained from the test rig (black dashed lines): (a) rotation velocity of 30 Hz, external excitation frequency of 20 Hz; (b) rotation velocity of 35 Hz, external excitation frequency of 20 Hz; (c) rotation velocity of 30 Hz, external excitation frequency of 25 Hz; (d) rotation velocity of 35 Hz, external excitation frequency of 25 Hz; (e) rotation velocity of 30 Hz, external excitation frequency of 30 Hz; and (f) rotation velocity of 35 Hz, external excitation frequency of 30 Hz.

Peaks due to the unbalance appear in all the cases, always in the positive frequencies of the rotational speed, because the unbalance is a synchronous force and causes a forward component of motion. The small peaks at the same frequencies, but in the negative parts of the spectrums, occur because of the anisotropy of the system,2 in this case, due to the hydrodynamic bearings. The damped peaks around 23 Hz in both sides of the spectrum, where also occur phase shifts, represent the first critical speed of the system, the forward and backward components.

In Figure 13(a) and (b), the excitation peaks at the frequency of 20 Hz are highest in the positive part of the spectrum, and consequently, the displacements are predominantly forward. When the excitation frequency is 25 Hz (Figure 13(c) and (d)), the peaks are highest in the negative part of the spectrum, featuring predominantly backward displacements.

This fact occurs because, even though the critical velocities are very close to each other, they do not overlap due to the anisotropy of the system. Therefore, the positive component of the first critical speed, related to the forward precession, is closer to excitation of 20 Hz and negative, related to the backward precession, is closer to the excitation frequency of 25 Hz.

When the excitation frequency is 30 Hz, Figure 13(e) and (f), it is distant enough from the critical speed (forward and backward) components, and the peaks are dominant at the rotation speed again. Therefore, the unbalance effect prevails, and the forward precession predominates over the backward one.

In order to have better understanding of this phenomenon, a series of simulations is presented at a constant rotational speed of 35 Hz, 4 s of duration, and the excitation frequency of the actuator varying from 15 to 30 Hz at a step of 0.1 Hz from one simulation to the next. Figure 14 shows the variation of the disc displacement full spectrum as the actuator excitation frequency is changed, and Figure 15 shows the peaks variation. These peaks variation are represented in Figure 14 by the different lines, which are also displayed in Figure 15; thus, Figure 15 is a lateral view of Figure 14. Figure 14.
Full spectrum variation due to actuator excitation frequency changing.
Figure 15.
Peaks variation due to actuator excitation frequency changing.

It can be observed from Figure 14 that the rotational speed peak (due to unbalance) is always in the frequency of 35 Hz with the same amplitude and represented by the black dotted line. The black line with circles and the bold line represent the forward and backward components, respectively, due to the magnetic actuator excitation.

Figure 15 shows that when the excitation frequency is far from the natural frequencies (either lower or higher), both component amplitudes (forward and backward) are very close, and it is not clear what component lightly dominates the shaft whirl. As the frequency of the magnetic force approaches the natural frequencies, their amplitudes starts to increase until they overlap the unbalance peak. Before 22.4 Hz, the positive component due to the actuator excitation is the higher peak of the spectrum; therefore, the direction of the shaft whirl, close and before 23 Hz, remains forward. At the frequency of 22.4 Hz, the negative component of the actuator excitation force became higher, i.e. the forward whirl changes to backward at the shaft rotation frequency of 23 Hz.

As mentioned before, this occurs because, although the two natural frequencies are close to each other and around 23 Hz, the forward frequency is lower and it is first excited. The peak of the backward component of the excitation force reaches higher amplitude because, as shown in Figure 4(b), the first forward natural frequency has a higher damping than the first backward.

The next set of simulations were made with the actuator force at a constant frequency of 25 Hz, 4 s of duration, and the rotational speed of the rotor varying from 15 to 40 Hz at a step of 0.25 Hz. Figure 16 shows the variation of the disc displacement full spectrum as the rotational speed is changed, and Figure 17 shows only the maximum amplitude peak of the positive (forward) and the negative (backward) parts of Figure 16. Therefore, in these figures, the objective is just to see the whirl direction, which is given by the direction of the highest magnitude of the full spectrum at the correspondent rotational speed. Figure 16.
Full spectrum variation due to rotational speed changing.
Figure 17.
Magnitude of the directional components due to the rotational speed changing.

In Figure 16, it can be observed that the forward and backward components of the actuator excitation peak at the constant frequencies of 25 Hz (gray bold) and −25 Hz (gray with circles), respectively. The black bold and black with circle lines are the forward and backward components of the rotational speed, respectively. As expected, the backward component of the rotational speed (black with circles) is very small, once the unbalance is a synchronous force and the bearing anisotropy is weak in this case. In the forward component (black bold), two peaks can be seen, the highest one when the rotor speed reaches the first forward critical speed (near 23 Hz) and the lowest one due to the combination of the unbalance and the actuator excitation force at 25 Hz. The backward component of the actuator force (gray with circles) is nearly constant.

As mentioned before, in order to simplify the identification of the precessional movement direction, Figure 17 shows only the maximum magnitudes of the forward (black solid) and backward (black dashed) parts of Figure 16. It can be seen that the whirl is predominantly forward when the rotational speed is near the critical speed (23 Hz) and near 25 Hz (unbalance effect combined with the actuator excitation). For the other rotational speeds, the whirl is predominantly backward because the actuator excitation is closer to the first backward natural frequency (which is a little higher than the first forward one).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study presents the complete model of a rotating system externally excited by a magnetic actuator. The mechanical model is shortly described, passing from the shaft FEM through the journal bearings model. The model of the magnetic actuator, which is the primary focus of this study, was progressively and didactically detailed since the derivation of the equations from the physics laws, until their interaction with the equations of the other components that compose the actuator system, and finally, their integration with the rotating system. It is important to highlight the experimental evidence of the backward whirl. Despite of the fact that no model adjustment methods were used, the comparison between simulated and experimental results showed that this model can satisfactorily represent the system for the intended application which is mainly the directional modal analysis of rotating machinery. The late series of simulations shows that the magnetic actuator can be used as an external excitation source in modal analysis, once it is capable to apply the desired force at the desired frequency, exciting both forward and backward whirling frequencies.
